channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-3519] junit regression test failure in testInertTime(org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.TimeHandlingTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<2> but was:<3>
item.description:
see ibm15 trunk testing:
http://people.apache.org/~myrnavl/derby_test_results/main/windows/testlog/ibm15/635136-suites.All_diff.txt
There were 2 failures:
1) testInertTime(org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.TimeHandlingTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<2> but was:<3>

item.summary: junit regression test failure in testInertTime(org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.TimeHandlingTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<2> but was:<3>

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I am also seeing these failures consistently in a sane, classes run against ibm15 on a laptop. I saw it 9 out of 9 times running full suite in this environment.
There were 2 failures:
1) testInertTime(org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.TimeHandlingTe

mpl.java:43)

at junit.extensions.TestDecorator.basicRun(TestDecorator.java:22)
at junit.extensions.TestSetup$1.protect(TestSetup.java:19)

I saw this on runs over the weekend but it seemed to only occur on Sunday, maybe related to the daylight savings change on Sunday in the US?
I saw the same error on my 10.3 codeline yesterday and I agree with Dan, I think it may have been related to daylight savings change(although I haven't run the test today to verify that).
I have verified that test no longer fails on the Monday after daylight savings time change. Lowering priority.

Happened again when changing to daylight saving time in Europe:
http://dbtg.thresher.com/derby/test/Daily/jvm1.6/testing/testlog/solN+1/759710-suitesAll_diff.txt

Test again failed when the US changed over time, so problem still exists. extremely dependent on exactly when test is run.
failed in trunk against ibm15, ibm16 and ibm17:
http://people.apache.org/~myrnavl/derby_test_results/main/windows/testlog/ibm15/1299515-suites.All_diff.txt
failed in 10.8 against ibm jvms also - here is an example:
http://people.apache.org/~myrnavl/derby_test_results/v10_8/windows/testlog/ibm142/1299518-suites.All_diff.txt
I saw this again last night; test box switched to daylight savings time. Oracle Linux, JDK 1.7.0_13, x86_64.

The problem happens around the day DST starts in the local timezone. The failing test inserts many random TIME values into a table and reads them back out. The failure happens when reading the TIME values using getTimestamp().

When reading a TIME value with getTimestamp(), Derby fills the date component of the timestamp with the values of the current date. DERBY-889 discusses why that's the right thing to do.

So, in the CET/CEST timezone at least, if the TIME value is between 2am and 3am, and getTimestamp() is called during the day DST starts, the hour component of the returned timestamp will be adjusted from 2 to 3, as there is no valid timestamp on that day for the hour between 2am and 3am. Since the test compares the time components of the timestamp and the original time value, and sees that they are different, it thinks the timestamp value was unexpected and fails.

The attached patch makes the test calculate the existing timestamp using the same conversion rules as Derby's JDBC drivers. I've verified that this makes the test pass when I change the time to March 31 (the day DST started in CET). It fails without the patch.

I also took the opportunity to do some other cleanup in TimeHandlingTest:

  • removed some unnecessary throws clauses
  • simplified some of the calendar manipulation methods
Since the Derby code also lives on GitHub... Here's the patch with nice colours: https://github.com/kahatlen/derby/commit/92dddea76269a2c44455d718c73d1213a4e1e326

Commit 1493156 from Kathey Marsden
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1493156 ]

DERBY-3519 junit regression test failure in testInertTime(org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.TimeHandlingTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<2> but was:<3>

merge from trunk revision 1464386. Contributed by Knut Anders Hatlen
